questions.text: All of the following are true about small bowel duplication except?

options.label: A
options.text: These are submucosa-lined structures in continuity with the GI tract

options.label: B
options.text: The most common site is the ileum

options.label: C
options.text: Cystic duplication is the most common type

questions.correct_answer: A. These are submucosa-lined structures in continuity with the GI tract
questions.explanation:
Cystic duplication:

Tubular duplication:
  • Most common - 75% cases (Option C)
  • It does not communicate with the lumen of the small intestine
  • Partial small bowel obstruction leads to:
    • Recurrent abdominal pain
    • Vomiting
  • 25% cases
  • Communicates with the lumen of the small intestine
    • If the proximal part communicates: Proximal duplication.
    • If the distal part communicates: Distal duplication.
  • Presence of ectopic gastric mucosa (ileal ulcer) → acid production → ulcer → bleeding → hematochezia.

questions.text: A 10-day-old female baby was brought to the OPD with the following findings as shown in the image given below. On examination there is no cough impulse in the swelling. X-ray examination shows the erosion of the coccyx. The most likely clinical diagnosis would be:
How will you manage a case of anorectal malformation with no visible fistula in a female patient with cross-table lateral X-ray showing rectum below the coccyx?

options.label: A
options.text: Protective colostomy followed by posterior sagittal anorectoplasty

questions.correct_answer: A. Protective colostomy followed by posterior sagittal anorectoplasty

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic methods is used to differentiate between a high and low lesion in anorectal malformation, and how does it determine the location of the rectum?

options.label: A
options.text: Abdominal ultrasound; identifies the rectal location by imaging the entire pelvic cavity.

options.label: B
options.text: MRI of the pelvis; differentiates based on the presence of anatomical anomalies in the pelvic floor

options.label: C
options.text: Invertogram; assesses the rectal termination by the rise of gas in relation to the pelvic floor.

options.label: D
options.text: X-ray of the pelvis; determines rectal termination based on bone structures and distance from the pelvic floor.

questions.correct_answer: C. Invertogram; assesses the rectal termination by the rise of gas in relation to the pelvic floor.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes a component and a step involved in the LADD's operation for managing intestinal malrotation?

options.label: A
options.text: Appendectomy; Division of LADD’s bands near the medial aspect of the duodenum

options.label: B
options.text: Reduction of volvulus; Widening of the mesenteric base by mobilizing the duodenum

options.label: C
options.text: Bowel repositioning; Resection of viable bowel wrapped in warm, moist sponges

options.label: D
options.text: Division of LADD’s bands; Placement of the duodenum and proximal jejunum on the left side of the abdomen

questions.correct_answer: B. Reduction of volvulus; Widening of the mesenteric base by mobilizing the duodenum

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with sudden-onset bilious vomiting and lethargy. The baby has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain and has not been gaining weight as expected. On examination, the infant shows signs of poor perfusion and decreased urine output. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what should be the primary investigation to confirm it?

options.label: A
options.text: Intestinal Malrotation with Midgut Volvulus; Upper GI Contrast Study

options.label: B
options.text: Pyloric Stenosis; Upper GI Contrast Study

options.label: C
options.text: Intestinal Malrotation with Midgut Volvulus; Barium Swallow Study

questions.correct_answer: A. Intestinal Malrotation with Midgut Volvulus; Upper GI Contrast Study

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about hyper-rotation of intestines?

options.label: A
options.text: The cecum is located in the left hypochondrium

options.label: B
options.text: The cecum is in the midline inferior to the pylorus

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of Ladd's bands is noticed

questions.correct_answer: A. The cecum is located in the left hypochondrium
questions.explanation:
Description

Abnormalities

Non-Rotation
  • Most common rotational abnormality.
  • Failure of counter-clockwise rotation after return of midgut to the abdominal cavity.
  • Duodenum (C-loop), Ligament of Treitz, and small intestine are on the right side.
  • Cecum and large intestine are on the left side.
  • Proximal jejunum and ascending colon fused as one pedicle.

Incomplete Rotation
  • Most common type of malrotation.
  • Arrested counter-clockwise rotation around 180° (Option C).
  • Small intestine lies on the right side.
  • DJ flexure located on the right side of the vertebral column.
  • Duodenum may have a corkscrew configuration.
  • Major part of the large intestine on the left side.
  • Cecum is close to midline.
  • Right colon located more medially.
  • Failure of fixation of ascending colon in right hypochondrium, leading to narrow intestinal mesentery and presence of Ladd's bands. (Option D)

Reverse Rotation
  • Rotation occurs in a clockwise direction around the SMA.
  • Duodenum is anterior to the superior mesenteric artery.
  • Transverse colon is posterior to the superior mesenteric artery.

Hyper-Rotation
  • Counter-clockwise rotation greater than 270°.
  • Cecum is located in the left hypochondrium (Option A).

Mixed Rotation
  • Intestine does not rotate as it enters the abdomen after a physiological hernia.
  • Cecum is located in the midline, inferior to the pylorus (Option B).
  • Increased risk of volvulus.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male baby is brought with complaints of irritable crying. Mother gave the history of not passing meconium in the first 48 hours of life. On examination, abdominal distension was seen with rebound tenderness and reduced bowel sounds. Identify the condition.

At 2 days of life, a male newborn becomes irritable and inconsolable. He is noted to have abdominal distension. He failed to pass meconium since being born. A follow-up barium enema shows microcolon and terminal ileum with meconium. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following statements about the meconium plug are false?

options.label: A
options.text: Associated with hypothyroidism and cystic fibrosis

options.label: B
options.text: X-ray of the abdomen shows the corkscrew's appearance

options.label: C
options.text: Water-soluble contrast enema is used for diagnosis and therapeutic purposes.

options.label: D
options.text: It is mostly seen in preterm infants.

questions.correct_answer: B. X-ray of the abdomen shows the corkscrew's appearance

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with recurrent chest infections and dyspnea. Chest CT reveals a 5 cm, well-defined, fluid-filled cystic lesion in the right paratracheal region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-ray of the abdomen is done, as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis you suspect?
questions.explanation:
Types

Feature

Type 1

Membranous atresia with intact bowel mesentery

Type 2

With an atretic cord between two blind ends of the bowel with intact mesentery

Type 3a

Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap

Type 3b

An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap

Type 4

Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance

questions.text: On observing the following finding in the X-ray of a baby with a history of Down’s syndrome, what is the most likely diagnosis you would suspect?

An 8-week-old infant is diagnosed with type 3 biliary atresia. The surgical team is planning the most appropriate intervention for this patient. Which of the following describes the preferred surgical approach for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Treatment
  • Exploratory laparotomy
  • Intra-operative Cholecysto-cholangiogram
    • To confirm the diagnosis,
    • Demonstrate fibrotic biliary remnant
    • Define absent proximal & distal bile duct patency
  • For Type 1- Roux-en-Y jejunal anastomosis
  • For Type 2 and above- Kasai Porto-enterostomy (TOC)
  • Liver transplantation may be required after 3 months.

Kasai portoenterostomy
  • Removal of gallbladder and bile duct in case of progressive obliteration
  • Division of jejunum, distal part taken, and proximal part anastomosed into the side of the jejunum

Postoperative drug therapy
  • UDCA (Facilitates bile flow)
  • Methylprednisolone (anti-inflammatory agent)
  • TMP-SMX (For antimicrobial prophylaxis)

Postoperative Complications

Most common: Cholangitis

Prognosis
  • No medical treatment can reverse the process of biliary atresia
  • If Surgery is not performed, death occurs within 2 years
  • Surgery should be done within 60 days of birth for better outcomes and survival
  • 30% of patients undergoing Portoenterostomy before 60 days of age have long-term successful survival & don't require liver transplantation

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to the pediatrician with persistent jaundice and pale, clay-colored stools. The parents report that the baby is not gaining weight as expected. On physical examination, the infant appears jaundiced and the liver is palpable 2 cm below the right costal margin. Which of the following diagnostic tests would be most specific for confirming the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features
  • Obstructive Jaundice at birth or some days after birth
  • Passage of acholic pale grey stools (due to obstructed bile flow)
  • Failure to thrive
  • Signs and symptoms of portal hypertension & hepatic failure (if diagnosis or treatment is delayed)
  • In 25% of cases - Associated malformations (Polysplenia, Malrotation, Preduodenal Portal Vein, Intrahepatic vena cava)

Pathological Hallmarks
  • Bile duct proliferation
  • Severe cholestasis with plugging
  • Inflammatory cell infiltrate

Diagnosis
  • Gold standard: Intraoperative/perioperative cholangiogram / cholecystocholangiogram (Option D)
  • USG Findings: Gallbladder is shrunken, CBD is not visible (Option A)
  • USG Signs: Gallbladder Ghost triad, triangular cord sign
  • Hepatobiliary scintigraphy: Uptake into the liver without any flow into the duodenum/excretion of radiotracer into the intestine (Option C)

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice and acholic stools. After initial workup, a congenital hepatobiliary disorder is suspected. Intraoperative cholangiography reveals complete obliteration of the common bile duct, cystic duct, and hepatic duct up to the porta hepatis. Based on the Kasai Classification, which type of this condition does this infant have?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Progressive obliteration of both intrahepatic & extrahepatic bile ducts

Incidence

1:1000 live births

Clinical Significance

Most common indication of pediatric liver transplantation

Pathological Hallmarks
  • Bile duct proliferation
  • Severe cholestasis with plugging
  • Inflammatory cell infiltrate

Disease Progression

Progresses to:

  • Cirrhosis
  • Portal hypertension
  • Hepatic failure

Kasai Classification
  • Type 1: Common bile duct (CBD) is obliterated with patent proximal bile duct & cystic duct (Option A)
  • Type 2A: Characterized by atresia of Common hepatic duct (CHD) with patent cystic duct & CBD (Option B)
  • Type 2B: Characterized by obliteration of CHD, Cystic duct & CBD (Option C)
  • Type 3 (MC type): Atresia of CBD, cystic duct & hepatic duct up to Porta hepatis (responsible > 90% of the cases) (Option D)

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with Type A Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). The surgical team is discussing treatment options based on the gap between the proximal and distal ends of the esophagus. On further investigations, the gap is considerably larger. Which of the following will be the correct management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Feeding gastrostomy followed by tension free Esophago-Esophagostomy

options.label: C
options.text: Excision of fistula tract + Tension-free esophago-esophagostomy.

options.label: D
options.text: Excision of fistula tract + repair of the defect.

questions.correct_answer: B. Feeding gastrostomy followed by tension free Esophago-Esophagostomy
questions.explanation:
Protocol
  • Confirm diagnosis of TEF
  • Determine the type of TEF (A, B, C, D, or E)
  • Assess for associated anomalies (VACTERL)

Diagnosis
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric tube into the stomach, with coiling in the esophagus suggests esophageal atresia (EA)
  • Presence of gas in GIT below the diaphragm is suggestive of TEF
  • For type E or H-type fistula diagnosis is confirmed by:
    • Tracheo-bronchoscopy (for the evaluation of the trachea)
    • Upper GI endoscopy (For the assessment of the esophagus)

Surgical Management

For Type A TEF (Isolated esophageal atresia without TEF):

  • a. For small gap: (Option A)
    • Perform tension-free Esophago-Esophagostomy
    • Suture proximal and distal ends
  • b. For large gap:
    • Perform feeding gastrostomy
    • Follow with delayed tension-free Esophago-Esophagostomy

For Types B, C, and D TEF (TEF with esophageal atresia): (Option C)

  • Excision of fistula tract
  • Perform tension-free esophago-esophagostomy

For Type E TEF (TEF without esophageal atresia): (Option D)

  • Excision of fistula tract
  • Repair of the defect

Prognosis

Mortality of TEF depends on the abnormalities:

  • Cardiac defects
  • Chromosomal abnormalities

questions.text: A newborn male presents with continuous drooling of saliva from the mouth and regurgitation of feeds given orally. When attempting to pass a nasogastric tube, the physician notices that it coils in the esophagus and cannot be passed into the stomach. X-ray reveals the presence of gas in the gastrointestinal tract below the diaphragm. Further evaluation reports the presence of cardiovascular abnormality. Which of the following cardiac abnormalities is most likely to be seen?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Fistula: Abnormal communication between 2 epithelialized surfaces
  • TEF: Abnormal communication between trachea & esophagus

Association
  • Esophageal atresia

Classification
  • Type A: Isolated esophageal atresia without TEF
  • Type B: Esophageal atresia with proximal TEF
  • Type C: Esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula (Most common type)
  • Type D: Esophageal atresia with both proximal + distal esophageal fistula (Least common type)
  • Type E: TEF without esophageal atresia or H-shaped fistula

Risk Factor
  • Maternal history of Polyhydramnios

Clinical Features
  • Continuous drooling of saliva from the mouth
  • Regurgitation of feeds given orally
  • If food or saliva enters the trachea:
    • Choking
    • Coughing
    • Cyanosis
    • Dyspnea

Diagnosis
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric tube into the stomach, with coiling in the esophagus suggests esophageal atresia (EA)
  • Presence of gas in GIT below the diaphragm is suggestive of TEF

Associated Abnormalities (VACTERL)
  • Vertebral body segmentation defect
  • Anal atresia
  • Cardiovascular anomalies (VSD, PDA): M/C anomaly.
    • Ventricular septal defect (VSD): M/C among cardiovascular defects
  • TEF
  • Renal abnormality (Unilateral renal agenesis)
  • Limb anomalies (Radial ray hypoplasia)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion. Chest X-ray shows an elevated left hemidiaphragm. Further imaging reveals thinning and upward displacement of the left hemidiaphragm without any defect. What is the most appropriate management?

A 20-year-old female presents with recurrent hemoptysis. CT angiography reveals a dense lesion in the left lower lobe with arterial supply from the descending thoracic aorta. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Intralobar sequestration (ILS)

Extralobar sequestration (ELS)
  • More common (75-90% of cases)
  • Located within normal lung tissue
  • Shares pleural covering with the normal lung
  • Usually diagnosed in adolescents or young adults
  • Common symptoms: recurrent pneumonia, hemoptysis
  • Venous drainage is typically to the pulmonary veins
  • Less common (10-25% of cases)
  • Separate from normal lung tissue with its own pleural covering
  • Usually diagnosed in infancy or early childhood
  • Often associated with other congenital anomalies
  • Venous drainage is typically to the systemic veins (Azygos, Hemiazygos vein, Venacava)
